newsitem.title: CZECH REPUBLIC: Czech PM Klaus says NATO call climax to reforms.
newsitem.headline: Czech PM Klaus says NATO call climax to reforms.

text.p: Czech Prime Minister Vaclav Klaus on Tuesday welcomed NATO's decision to invite the Czech Republic to join the alliance, saying the enlargement decision was the culmination of post-Communist reforms.
Speaking to reporters minutes after receiving the news from the Madrid NATO summit, Klaus said his country was ready to bear the responsibility and costs of membership, scheduled for 1999.
"For this country it is an historic moment...an exceptionally important step was made for our future, for our security, for our position in Europe and in the whole world," Klaus said.
"It is the culmination of the whole process following November (1989, when communist rule ended)," he said.
"We know NATO entry is not a one-way street, we cannot be only passive participants of this security grouping, we want to be an active link."
Klaus added that admission negotiations would start "without delay".
He reiterated that the Czech Republic was ready to increase military spending to two percent of gross domestic product from the current 1.7 percent over the next few years.
